p.hi:
[Translated from the German of Alexander Von Humboldt,
by G. P. P.]

div.head: THE SOUTHERN CROSS.
div.p:
Since we entered the tropic zone we could not
sufficiently admire every night the beauty of the
southern sky, which, as we advanced toward the
South, disclosed new constellations to our eyes.—
We feel a peculiar sensation as we approach the
equator, and particularly as we go from one hemi-
sphere to the other, when we see the stars, which
we have known from our earliest infancy gradually
sink and at last disappear. Nothing more vividly
reminds a traveler of his vast distance from his
native land than the aspect of an unknown sky.—
The grouping of the large stars, several scattered
nebulæ, which vie in splendor with the milky way,
and spaces which are distinguished by their ex-
traordinary blackness, give a singular physiogno-
my to the Southern sky. This spectacle fills with
deep emotion those who, without instruction in
the higher sciences, behold the vault of heaven
with the same pleasure as they admire a beauti-
ful landscape or a magnificent scene. One need
not be a botanist to recognize the torrid zone by
the mere appearance of its vegetation. Without
any knowledge of astronomy, and without any
acquaintance with the celestial maps of FlamstradFlamsteed
or de la LailleCaille, we feel that we are not in Europe
when we see the huge constellation of the Ship,
or the phosphorescent clouds of Magellan arise
on the horizon. The earth and the sky, every-
thing in the equinoctial regions assumes an ex-
otic character.

The lower regions of the air were impregnated
with vapors for some days. We saw distinctly for
the first time the Southern Cross, on the night of
the 4th and 5th of July, in the 16th degree of lati-
tude. It was strongly inclined, and appeared from
time to time between clouds, whose centre fur-
rowed with sheet-lightning, threw back a silver-
colored light. If a traveller may be allowed to
speak of his personal emotions, I would add that
on this night I saw one of the dreams of my early
youth fulfilled.

When we we begin to look at geographical maps
and to read the narratives of travelers, we feel for
certain lands and climates a sort of predilection,
for which we cannot give an account in after life.
These impressions have a marked influence over
our resolutions, and we, as it were, instinctively
seek to place ourselves in connection with the ob-
jects, which for a long time have had for us a
mysterious charm. At the time when I studied
the heavens, not with a view to devote myself to
astronomy, but to learn the names of the stars, I
was moved with an awe which is unknown to those
who lead a sedentary life. It seemed painful to
me to renounce the hope of seeing the beautiful
constellations, which lie near the Southern pole.—
Impatient to travel through the equatorial re-
gions, I could not lift up my eyes to the starry
vault of heaven without thinking of the Cross of
the South, and without recalling to memory the
sublime passage of Dante, which the most re-
nowned commentators have applied to this con-
stellation:

lg.l: “To the right hand I turned, and fixed my mind
On the other pole attentive, where I saw
Four stars ne’er seen before, save by the ken
Of our first parents. Heaven of their rays
Seemed joyous. O thou northern site! bereft
Indeed, and widowed, since of these deprived”

div.p:
The satisfaction we felt, on the discovery of the
Cross of the South was warmly participated in
by those of the crew who had lived in the Colo-
nies. In the loneliness of the sea we greet a star
as a friend, from whom we have been separated
for a long time. Among the Spaniards and Por-
tuguese peculiar motives seem to deepen the in-
terest. A religious feeling makes them love a
constellation which calls to their memory the
sign of the faith which their ancestors planted in
the deserts of the new world.

Since the two great stars which designate the
top and base of the Cross have nearly the same
right ascension, the constellation is almost perpen-
dicular at the moment when it goes through
the meridian. All who live beyond the tropics or
in the Southern hemisphere are aware of this fact.
It has been observed, at what time of night, in dif-
ferent seasons of the year, the Cross of the South
is erect or inclined. This is a clock, which ad-
vances pretty regularly about four minutes a day,
and no other constellation presents so ready an op-
portunity of observing the time at a single glance.
How often have we heard guides say in the Savan-
nahs of Venezuela or in the desert which stretches
from Lima to Truxillo: “Midnight is past, the
Cross begins to bend!” How often have these
words reminded us of the pathetie scene, when
Paul and Virginia, sitting at the source of the riv-
er Lataniers, conversed together for the last time,
and when the old man, looking at the Cross of the
South, reminds them that it is time to separate.
